Core::Processor Class Reference
[Core]

KAAPI ProcessorProcessor manages scheduling of a set of threads with at most one active thread at any time. A processor implements the interface signal to handles the signalization mechanism on specific execution points. A processor is attached with an executing thread of control and a native thread of control may be attached to a processor. More...

Detailed Description

KAAPI Processor

Processor manages scheduling of a set of threads with at most one active thread at any time. A processor implements the interface signal to handles the signalization mechanism on specific execution points. A processor is attached with an executing thread of control and a native thread of control may be attached to a processor.

void * Core::Processor::allocate (  )  [inline]

Alloc a bloc. Tries to get it from cached list else do normal through allocate_memory

void * Core::Processor::allocate ( size_t   )  [inline, virtual]

Allocation/liberation operators Inherited from Util::InterfaceAllocator Alloc a bloc for a thread. If requested size if greather than util.stacksize, then the caller should re-run its application using a bigger value for the stacksize. Tries to get it from cached list else do normal through allocate_memory

Implements Util::InterfaceAllocator.

void Core::Processor::attach ( Core::Thread *  th  ) 

Attach a new core thread to the current processor Add a new child thread to the current processor. The processor of the thread is set to this. Implementation add the new thread in the back of a queue. Any thread should has been attached to a processor before it is started.

Warning:
the processor (this) should be locked before method invocation
Parameters:
th is the new child thread to be attached to the current processor
void Core::Processor::attach_host_thread (  ) 

Attach the processor to the running posix thread If a processor is already attached to the running posix thread, then do nothing. The processor doesnot have any active thread that must be set by the caller. The processor is not attached to any workset.

Reimplemented from Util::Thread.

void Core::Processor::attach_host_thread_suspended (  ) 

Attach the processor to the running posix thread If a processor is already attached to the running posix thread, then do nothing. The processor doesnot have any active thread that must be set by the caller. The processor is not attached to any workset.

Reimplemented from Util::Thread.

void Core::Processor::suspend ( Core::Thread *  thread,
Core::Condition *  rstate,
Core::Condition::State  waiting_state,
bool  test_isqual = true 
)

Thread management suspend execution of thread because of a condition not statisfied. This method should be called by the thread of control attached to the 'thread' object. The thread should be attached to this processor object before calling this method. The method block the running thread (should be the thread) until the condition object rstate has the same state than the waiting state. If the flag 'test_isqual' is true then the test is the equality test to satisfy the condition. If the flag is false, then the test is the 'not equal' test. On return to the call the following post condition is true ((rstate->get_state() == waiting_state) && test_isequal) || ((rstate->get_state() != waiting_state) && !test_isequal)

Warning:
The method lock the 'thread' object.
Parameters:
thread the thread that will be suspend
rstate the pointer to the condition for which we are waiting a specific state
waiting_state the value of the state for waiting for
test_isqual true/false see documentation
void Core::Processor::terminate (  )  [virtual]

Terminate the thread

Exceptions:
PosixError with error code if error occurs

Reimplemented from Util::Thread.

bool Core::Processor::wakeup_thread ( Processor *  idle_processor,
Core::Thread *&  victim_thread 
)

Try to wakeup at most one waiting thread The method try to wakeup a thread that is sleeping on a condition, i.e. thread that is in the list of waiting threads. If the return value is true then victim_thread points to the thread that could be wakeup and the thread is erased from the list. The thread is resumed, and the called should not do anything. If this method is called by the other processor then it tries to resume thread using the last in first out (FIFO) order on the suspend events of threads. If this method is called by the current processor then it tries to resume thread using the last in first out (LIFO) order on the suspend events of threads.

Returns:
return true if one waiting thread may be wakeup
